G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3, which grants jurisdiction to the Housing Court over claims involving residential landlord-tenant relationships.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Massachusetts law provides that a landlord may not do or fail to do any act that interferes with a tenant's use and quiet enjoyment of a leased property.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 95 (19.raw_text: *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 95 (1982) (holding that landlords who fail to remedy conditions that substantially interfere with tenants' enjoyment of leased property violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment).
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 95 (19.proposition: Defendant's actions and inactions constitute a substantial interference with Plaintiff's quiet enjoyment of the premises in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, and case law including *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 95 (1982) (holding that landlords who fail to remedy conditions that substantially interfere with tenants' enjoyment of leased property violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment).
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 95 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the covenant of quiet enjoyment, holding that a landlord who, at least recklessly, fails to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions—thereby allowing repeated flooding that substantially interferes with a tenant’s use of the premises—violates the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. The court explains that ‘quiet enjoyment’ covers serious interferences with the character and value of the leased premises and that liability does not require specific intent, but extends to at least reckless omissions to act. This matches the proposition that a landlord’s failure to remedy conditions that substantially interfere with a tenant’s enjoyment violates quiet enjoyment under § 14 and related case law.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 95 (19.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute. … Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg. V.raw_text: *Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg. Voc. Tech. Sch. Dist.*, 461 Mass. 366, 374 (2012).
*Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg. V.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act in a reasonable and timely manner also violates the standard of care set forth in *Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg. Voc. Tech. Sch. Dist.*, 461 Mass. 366, 374 (2012).
*Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg. V.case_name: Town of Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Regional Vocational Technical High School District
*Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg. V.support_reasoning: The opinion is a statutory and constitutional case about school funding obligations and municipal standing; it does not address tort law, negligence, or any standard of care regarding a defendant’s reasonable or timely conduct. The cited page (374) concerns the Rule 12(b)(6) standard of review and pleading sufficiency, not a duty of care or breach analysis. Using Dartmouth for a negligence ‘standard of care’ proposition mischaracterizes the case and its holding.
*Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg. V.relevant_excerpt: “In reviewing the allowance of a motion to dismiss under Mass. R. Civ. P. 12 (b) (6), we examine the same pleadings as the motion judge and therefore proceed de novo… We consider whether the factual allegations in the complaint are sufficient, as a matter of law, to state a recognized cause of action or claim, and whether such allegations plausibly suggest an entitlement to relief.” (461 Mass. at 374).

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.proposition: The unusable condition of the second bedroom constitutes a material breach that justifies compensatory damages under Massachusetts landlord-tenant law, as recognized in *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 715-716 (1977).
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.support_reasoning: Blackett v. Olanoff concerns constructive eviction and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment due to excessive noise from a bar, not the unusable condition of a specific room such as a second bedroom. The opinion focuses on whether the landlords’ conduct and control over the noisy lounge barred them from collecting rent; it does not address partial uninhabitability of a unit or compensatory damages for loss of a particular bedroom. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge.”
